container-title: Al-Ashraf Khalil (r. 1290–93): Mamluk sultan of Egypt who took the city of Acre in May 1291, an event seen as the conclusion of the Crusades in the region
title: bishop of Le Puy, appointed papal legate for the First Crusade by Pope Urban II, served as unifying force for the disparate crusading armies, and died after the fall of Antioch
1081–1118): Byzantine emperor who sent an appeal to Pope Urban II for help against the Seljuk Turks, which resulted in the First Crusade
996–1021): caliph of Egypt who persecuted Christians and Jews, and also ordered the destruction of the Church of the Holy Sepulcher in Jerusalem in 1009

Ayyubid sultan of Egypt who defended the region from the advances of the Fifth Crusade and negotiated a treaty with Frederick II for the return of Jerusalem to Christian hands. ‘Ali ibn Tahir al-Sulami (ca 1040–1106): Damascus religious scholar, one of the first to call for jihad against the crusaders

note: Amalric (r. 1163–74): king of Jerusalem, younger brother of Baldwin III who died childless. Led several unsuccessful campaigns to capture Egypt. Died of dysentery and succeeded by his 13-year-old son, Baldwin IV (r. 1174–85).
title: British general who led the Sinai and Palestine Campaign during World War I, including the capture of Jerusalem from the Ottoman Turks on

note: Baldwin of Boulogne (r. 1100–18): first king of Jerusalem, who succeeded his brother Godfrey, who had founded the Christian county of Edessa in 1098.
title: Anna Comnena (1083–ca 1153): daughter of Emperor Alexius I who was witness to the crusaders arriving in Constantinople and wrote the Alexiad, with information on the Byzantine imperial court and their interactions with the early crusaders
a leader of the Fourth Crusade who was chosen to be the first Latin emperor of Constantinople. Died in captivity after the battle of Adrianople
1174–85): the “leper king” and son of Amalric who ascended the throne of Jerusalem at 13

note: and negotiated with Saladin for the surrender of Jerusalem.
title: Balian of Ibelin (ca 1140–93): a crusader whose family rose from the lower ranks of knights to become lords of Rama (Ramlah). He was a participant in the battle of Hattin in

Mamluk slave who served as a commander under the Ayyubid sultan of Egypt and then as sultan. Responsible for a successful campaign against the Franks, retaking much of the remaining Latin territory in the Levant
The Thunderbolt,” the Ottoman sultan who defeated the crusaders at the battle of Nicopolis in 1396. Later captured and killed at the battle of Ankara

container-title: a treatise extolling the virtues of the Templars. The principal preacher of the Second Crusade and crusading in the Baltic
title: 1090–1153): Cistercian abbot and reformer, the author of the “Rule of the Templars” and “In Praise of the New Knighthood

container-title: which brought about the end to the Albigensian conflict
title: queen of the French king Louis VIII, she became regent to her son Louis IX from 1226–34. Responsible for the “Peace of Paris
1431–47): called the fifteenth-century Varna Crusade. Negotiated with the Byzantine emperor John VIII for the unification of the eastern and western churches under the authority of the papacy

container-title: Conquered the Muslim state of Granada in 1492 and expelled Muslims and Jews from the kingdom
title: 1479–1516): king of Aragon, married to Isabella of Castile

note: Innocent III, pope (r. 1198–1216): administrative pope, an active supporter of the Crusades, who instigated the Fourth Crusade, proclaimed the Albigensian Crusade, and promoted crusading in the Baltic regions and Spain.
title: 1099): the Fatimid governor of Jerusalem, he negotiated safe passage to Ascalon for himself and his garrison upon the fall of the city to the forces of the First Crusade

note: He and his order were accused of heresy and witchcraft by the French crown. Condemned as a heretic and burned in 1314.
title: 1474–1504): queen who ruled Spain with her husband, Ferdinand of Aragon, from 1481. Expelled Jews and Muslims after 1492. Isabella of Jerusalem (r. 1190–1205): gained the crown of Jerusalem upon her half sister Sibylla’s death in 1190. Married to Conrad of Montferrat in this year and, upon his death

remarried first to the nephew of Richard I, Henry of Champagne, and on his death in 1198 to King Amalric of Cyprus. James of Molay (ca 1243–1314): the last grand master of the Templars, who moved the order to Paris after their expulsion from Palestine
Byzantine emperor who sought aid from Pope Eugenius IV against the Ottoman Turks and signed a document agreeing to the unification of eastern and western churches under the authority of the papacy

note: John of Joinville (1224–1317): knight in the service of Louis IX who accompanied his king on crusade to Egypt and wrote the Life of Saint Louis.
title: 1456): lord of Transylvania and later regent for the king of Hungary, led forces in the Crusade of Varna and defeated an Ottoman force in the 1456 siege of Belgrade
1092–1107): Seljuk sultan of Rum Anatolia who was responsible for the destruction of the People’s Crusade but lost his capital Nicaea to the First Crusade in 1097
French king and husband of Eleanor of Aquitaine who led the Second Crusade along with Conrad III of Germany. His army suffered heavy losses and he was forced to retreat after failing to gain Damascus
1223–26): king of France and husband of Blanche of Castile who helped to launch the Albigensian Crusade

note: pope (r. 1417–31): pope whose election to the papacy ended the Great Western/Papal Schism. Declared the Hussite Crusade in 1420.
title: 1203): made a count by the German emperor, administered Sicily, and became regent for the infant Frederick II in 1198. Pope Innocent III offered indulgences to anyone who opposed him, instigating one of the first “political crusades
countess of Tuscany and protector of the papacy who fought against the German emperors Henry IV and Henry V and also supported a select group of clergy to develop the idea of holy or penitential war

container-title: who united Turkish forces and took Constantinople in 1453
title: Ottoman ruler known as “the Conqueror
1421–44 and 1446–51): Ottoman sultan known for his conquests in the Balkans and in particular his victory against the crusaders at the Battle of Varna in 1444

container-title: Was unable to check the rise of Saladin in Egypt
title: 1212): a German youth who led one of the two so-called Children’s Crusades. Nur al-Din (r. 1146–74): son of Zengi, captured Damascus in 1154 and consolidated Muslim rule in Syria. A Sunni ruler, he suppressed Shi’a teachings and practices

container-title: Killed by American Special Forces in
note: Pelagius (d. 1224): cardinal and papal legate for the Fifth Crusade who controlled the funding for the campaign and clashed with King John of Jerusalem over negotiations with al-Kamil, the Ayyubid sultan of Egypt.
title: Wendish overlord of the pagan Abotrites who fought with Christian neighbors over bordering territory, the cause of the Wendish Crusade of 1147. Was killed by the forces of Henry the Lion, duke of Saxony. Osama bin Laden/Usama ibn Ladin (1957–2011): born in Saudi Arabia, condemned foreign western powers, participated in the Afghan war against the Soviet takeover of Afghanistan, and in 1988 founded the terrorist movement al-Qaeda (“the Base”). Orchestrated 9/11 attacks in 2001
1186–90): sister of Baldwin IV, king of Jerusalem, and later queen of Jerusalem who participated in negotiations between the kingdom and Saladin

lord who abandoned the Fourth Crusade after its attack on Zara. Later led the Albigensian Crusade, gaining the lands of noble families throughout southern France and becoming count of Toulouse in 1213

note: but was killed at the battle of Ramla in 1102.
title: count of Blois and son-in-law of William the Conqueror who took part in the First Crusade, deserted during the siege of Antioch, returned to the First Crusade in 1101

note: Suleiman I (r. 1520–66): Ottoman sultan known as “the Magnificent” who extended the Ottoman Empire, taking Rhodes and besieging Vienna.
title: 1212): one of two leaders of the so-called Children’s Crusade, a young French shepherd who had a vision of Christ and made his way to Paris with a large entourage of young and older followers

note: Timur/Tamerlane (r. 1370–1405): warrior of Turkish origin, proclaimed khan, attacked Persia, and plundered and destroyed the kingdom of Delhi in India. Defeated the Ottoman forces at the battle of Ankara in 1401.
title: Tancred of Hauteville (d. 1112): nephew of Bohemund of Taranto, he joined him on the First Crusade, became prince of Galilee, and later served as regent and then prince of Antioch

note: Called the First Crusade at the Council of
title: 1088–99): a reforming, monarchical pope who trained as a monk of Cluny and was made cardinal in 1080. Served as Gregory VII’s legate to Germany and France
